conclusion: Determine the length of the arc AC where light rays cannot exit through AB or BC after the first incidence.
Refractive index of the material is n = 2, and AC is an arc with radius R.
Since ABCO forms a square, the length of OC is equal to the length of OA, which is R. Therefore, the length of AB is also R.
The critical angle for total internal reflection is given by sin θc = 1/n = 1/2, implying θc = 30°.
For light to exit through AB or BC after first incidence on arc AC, angle of incidence must be less than critical angle.
Angle of incidence is angle between incident ray and normal to surface at point of incidence.
Normal to surface at any point on arc AC is perpendicular to radius at that point.
Maximum angle of incidence for light to exit through AB is 90° - θc = 60°.
Maximum angle of incidence for light to exit through BC is also 90° - θc = 60°.
Angle θ is angle between radius and incident ray.
For light to have angle of incidence greater than 60°, θ must be such that 90° - θ > 60°, which simplifies to θ < 30°.
As light travels along arc AC, angle θ varies.
Maximum value of θ is 90° and minimum value is 30°.
Length of arc where θ < 30° is part where light cannot exit through AB or BC.
Total angle of arc is 270° since ACBO is a square and AC is an arc.
Angle where light can exit through AB or BC is 180° - 2 × 30° = 120°.
Length of arc where light cannot exit is (270° - 120°)/360° × 2πR = 5πR/6.
Length of arc in terms of angle is (270° - 120°)/360° × 2R = 5R/6.
